What‚Äôs on the Meningitis Encephalitis Panel (MEP)?

BACTERIA: E. coli (strain K1 only), H. flu, Listeria monocytogenes, N. meningitidis, S. agalactiae (Group B Strep), S. pneumoniae VIRUSES*: CMV, Enterovirus, HSV-1, HSV-2, Parechovirus, VZV FUNGI: Cryptococcus neoformans/gattii

*Note: HHV-6 is also tested, but these results are not routinely reported since HHV-6 is more commonly detected due to chromosomal integration or reactivation as opposed to true infection, except in immunocompromised patients. If no HSV is detected but concern for this virus remains, continue acyclovir and repeat lumbar puncture in 2-4 days for HSV PCR. In neonates, swabs of eye/throat/rectum or vesicles for HSV culture and blood for HSV PCR should also be sent to improve diagnostic accuracy. CSF may be PCR negative in some enterovirus or parechovirus infections, so consider sending throat and rectal swabs and/or serum for enterovirus and/or parechovirus PCR to improve virus recovery.

Bacterial Meningitis

Clinical presentation:

  • Fevers
  • Seizures (this can be the only initial symptom at presentation in neonates and infants <12 month ‚Äì AAP says to strongly consider LP for even simple febrile seizure if poorly vaccinated and 6-12 mo)
  • Meningismus (nuchal rigidity, photophobia, headache, can test Brudzinski‚Äôs ‚Äì involuntary lifting of legs with neck flexion, Kernig‚Äôs ‚Äì hip and thigh flexed at 90 degrees results in painful extension at the knee) ‚Äì only 5-30% sensitive, but 95-100% specific. Unreliable/less sensitive in infants.
  • Etiology by age:

Neonate

GBS, enteric GNegs (e.coli), listeria,

1 mo to 23 mo

N. men, strep pneumo, H. flu, E.coli, GBS

> 2 yo

Strep pneumo, N. men, listeria (others: h. flu, GNegs)

Evaluation:

  • Antibiotics should not be delayed for testing if clinical suspicion is present
  • Procalcitonin (>5.0 ug/L has sens 94%, spec 100% for bacterial meningitis)
  • CRP ‚Äì Normal CRP has high negative predictive value for bacterial meningitis
  • LP ‚Äì CT before if risk of increased ICP‚Ä¶ (suggestions based on adult study that have increased chance of abnormal neuroimaging)
  • Papilledema
  • Focal neurologic findings
  • History of CNS disease
  • New onset seizures (within one week)
  • Symptoms of imminent herniation
  • +/- AMS, immunocompromised state
  • Initial CSF Testing
  • Cell count with diff, glucose, protein, bacterial culture, MEP

Treatment:

¬∑ Role of steroids:

¬∑ Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg/day IV divided q6 x2-4 days (10mg q6 for adults) reduces sequelae (esp hearing loss) of H. flu and Strep pneumo

¬∑ Give steroids 10-20 minutes before antibiotics, less benefit if Rx already given, but the sooner the better. Do not delay antibiotics if steroids not available immediately.

¬∑ Antimicrobials (see dosing table below)

¬∑ Neonate: ampicillin and cefotaxime or ceftriaxone

¬∑ Children/Adults: ceftriaxone/cefotaxime and vanc (for resistant S. pneumo, not necessarily for Staph)

¬∑ Post-neurosurgery, CSF shunt, or penetrating trauma: cefepime/ceftazidime/meropenem and vanc

Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg/dose (max 2g) q12h

Cefepime 50mg/kg/dose (max 2g) q8h

Vancomycin 15mg/kg/dose q6h Goal trough 15-20

References:

¬∑ Infectious Disease Society of America. Practice Guidelines for the Management of Bacterial Meningitis.

Viral Meningitis

Clinical Presentation: same as bacterial above though course can be more indolent

Evaluation:

  • LP (see profiles below)
    • Viral testing:
      • MEP (Meningitis Encephalitis Panel: PCR for e.coli, h.flu, listeria, n.meningitidis, GBS, S.pneumo, CMV, EV, HSV 1&2, HHV6, parechovirus, VZV, Cryptococcus)
  • Etiology by season:
    • Most common cause of viral meningitis ‚Äì EV (>80% in children), late summer early fall predominance
    • Approximately 5% HSV (II>I for meningitis ‚Äì opposite in encephalitis)
    • Failure to identify a specific pathogen is not uncommon

Treatment:

  • HSV ‚Äì IV acyclovir 10mg/kg q8h (children); IV acyclovir 20/kg q8h (neonates). Recommend IV hydration and close monitoring of Cr as can crystallize and cause AKI.

Acute Flaccid Myelitis

Symptoms: >90% with preceding mild URI or febrile viral illness. Acute onset flaccid paralysis of one or more extremities or cranial neuropathies (facial palsy, bulbar weakness, diplopia); can be asymmetric

DDx: Includes EV-68, EV-71, WNV, polio, MOGAD, NMO, spinal cord stroke

MRI: In enteroviral infections - Dorsal brainstem and longitudinally extensive spinal grey matter hyperintensity, usually non-enhancing, +/- nerve root enhancement

LP: Pleocytosis common

Tx: None proven to be effective. IVIG is used most widely. Steroids worsened outcome in some animal models but could be considered if large degree of spinal cord edema resulting in UMN deficits.

Full summary of recommendations: https://www.cdc.gov/acute-flaccid-myelitis/hcp/clinical-management.html

EV-71 related meningomyeloencephalitis

Symptoms

¬∑ Fever, vomiting, ataxia, myoclonic jerks (especially during sleep), CN dysfunction

¬∑ Truncal hypotonia, limb weakness (AFM), urinary retention

¬∑ Autonomic dysfunction + acute cardiorespiratory collapse

o Arrythmias, pulmonary edema/hemorrhage

Testing

¬∑ LP

¬∑ CSF EV testing- low sensitivity (27%)

¬∑ EV rectum/throat/respiratory swab ‚Äì high sensitivity (95%)

o If no enterovirus is found, consider other possibilities (NMO, MOG, etc)

¬∑ MRI WWO at least of brain; usually C/T spine as well

o Sensitivity ~80%

o Most commonly dorsal rhomboencephalitis with T2 hyperintensity encircling 4th ventricle

o May show hyperintensity of the spinal grey matter

o Leptomeningeal enhancement (17%)

¬∑ ESR, CRP, WBC may be normal

Treatment

¬∑ None proven to alter outcome

¬∑ Typical practice has been to use IVIG in cases of brainstem encephalitis with autonomic dysfunction or acute flaccid myelitis

o Can consider steroids if refractory to IVIG

¬∑ Supportive care

o PT/OT/SLP +/- Rehab

o CR monitoring

o Post-void residuals

Prognosis (small study)

¬∑ Most children with resolution of symptoms by ~30 days

¬∑ Encephalomyelitis or cardiopulmonary failure ‚Äì may still have symptoms at 30 days

¬∑ Unclear long-term outcomes

COVID-19 and Neurologic Sequelae

Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C):

¬∑ An individual aged <21 years presenting with fever*, laboratory evidence of inflammation**, and evidence of clinically severe illness requiring hospitalization, with multisystem (>2) organ involvement (cardiac, renal, respiratory, hematologic, gastrointestinal, dermatologic or neurological); AND

¬∑ No alternative plausible diagnoses; AND

¬∑ Positive for current or recent SARS-CoV-2 infection by RT-PCR, serology, or antigen test; or exposure to a suspected or confirmed COVID-19 case within the 4 weeks prior to the onset of symptoms.

*Fever >38.0¬∞C for ‚â•24 hours, or report of subjective fever lasting ‚â•24 hours **Including, but not limited to, one or more of the following: an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), fibrinogen, procalcitonin, d-dimer, ferritin, lactic acid dehydrogenase (LDH), or interleukin 6 (IL-6), elevated neutrophils, reduced lymphocytes and low albumin

Neurologic Presentations:

¬∑ CNS case presentations: Meningoencephalitis, Acute ischemic stroke (particularly LVO in patients < 50y), Acute necrotizing encephalopathy, demyelinating disease, vertigo, headache, seizures, cerebellar ataxia

¬∑ PNS case presentations: anosmia and ageusia, Guillain-Barre syndrome and Miller-Fisher syndrome possible (tenuous evidence to support GBS and MFS associations, anosmia most common)

¬∑ ‚ÄúLong COVID‚Äù or ‚ÄúCOVID long-haulers‚Äù = description of increasingly recognized patient population who experience symptoms > 28 days after viral infection. Commonly described symptoms are persistent myalgias, ‚Äúbrain fog‚Äù, headaches, generalized weakness, or dizziness.
